newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Mid-Atlantic power steady to down on weather.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Mid-Atlantic power steady to down on weather.

text.p: U.S. Mid-Atlantic spot electricity was trading steady to lower Friday on forecasts of below-normal temperatures through to the end of August and speculation there may be little summer heat left to boost air conditioner use, industry sources said.
"Winter is here," said one East Coast-based physicals trader, who added the market could see price hikes into September if the East experiences any late heatwaves.

Prices in the Pennsylvania-New Jersey-Maryland (PJM) power pool for firm, on peak delivery over the weekend were talked in the $18.00-19.00 range, while Monday power was talked at $21.00-22.00. Next-day power was discussed at $29.00-31.00 per megawatt hour (MWh) on Thursday.
Off-peak power for the weekend was assessed at $14.00-16.00 per MWh.
Power for the five business days of next week was assessed lower in the $20.00-22.00 range from talk at $21.00-22.00 on Thursday, the brokers and marketers said.

September PJM for firm, peak delivery, was discussed relatively steady to slightly higher at $21.50-22.35 from a range of $21.50-22.00 on Thursday. PJM power for the fourth quarter of 1996 was talked at $22.30-22.50, the sources said.
-- Chris Reese, New York Power Desk 212-859-1627
